reviewText: Touted as the "soap that wouldn't die" Dark Shadows continues in it's best format yet, a reasonably priced 4 disc set. Although the show at this point in time is still in black & white, repleat with all it's flubs, flaws and technical difficulties, the magic of it's supernatural intrigue still stands up as one of the most unique gothic soaps of its time. There is no special pandering here, because of the master tapes that MPI had to work with, but it is still worth the price of admission to see these great shows. Liberally stolen from the great gothic classics, the storylines are predictable but with what they had to work with, it is still ahead of its time. The storyline in this set revolves around the Collinss family vampire, Barnabas Collins almost insane with undying love for his lost fiance, Josette, from his life before vampirism, sees a resemblance in the present day Maggie Evans, a barmaid from Collisport, has put the bite on her and has kidnapped her and is holding her in the basement of the Old House mansion where his ancestors in present time have let him take up residence. The family believes him to be a descendant of the original Barnabas Collins, unbeknownst to them he is the original Barnabas, a 175 year old vampire. A strange ghostly figure of a young girl dressed in old fashioned clothing appears to Maggie and Willie, Barnabas' manservant (shades of Renfrew!)Although Barnabas has not met this mysterious girl, she tells Willie she lives at the Old House! Who is this mysterious stranger? Also, in subsequent storylines, Elizabeth, the matriarch of the estate is being blackmailed by Jason McGuire adangerous drifter who knows a secret from her past and is trying to force her to marry him, much to the dismay of her brother Roger and daughter, Carolyn. Posing as a historian, Dr. Julia Hoffman arrives at Collinwood to spy on the collins family who seem to be the center of mysterious attacks in the area where townsfolk are found dead, drained of there blood! In the tradition of Dracula and Wuthering Heights, Dark Shadows stands alone as a gothic classic, destined to classic TV status. Although nothing here has been greatly improved, the DVDs are very good quality and on the right sound system have great sound and picture quality considering they are produced in mono. Buying them from Amazon at pre-order status guarantees a great price tag also, for a series that will contain at least 25 collections by the time they are all released. A great buy!
summary: Mystery and gothic suspense at it's best!

reviewText: DARK SHADOWS has become a classic for being the first soap opera to revolve around supernatural horror, and to do so while keeping its characters believable and its situations plausible.As this installment begins, DS's most famous character. the 175-year-old vampire Barnabas Collins, is passing himself off as a cousin from England, while secretly holding waitress Maggie Evans prisoner.  Maggie escapes, in a nearly catatonic state, with the help of a mysterious little girl named Sarah, who appears to her and several others.  Maggie is sent to Windcliff, a sanitarium run by Dr. Julia Hoffman, who finds Maggie's case especially fascinating.Back at Collinwood, Jason McGuire is blackmailing Elizabeth Stoddard into marrying him.  In protest, Elizabeth's daughter Carolyn threatens to marry a hippie biker named Buzz.  At the pivotal moment, Elizabeth reveals the secret she and Jason have been keeping between them.  But there's a REAL secret  Jason has been keeping from Elizabeth.  Jason ultimately has a run-in with Barnabas.Barnabas invites the family to a dinner party to celebrate his restoration of the Old House.  His goal is to attract Victoria, but his plan backfires when the family decides to hold a seance.Meanwhile, Dr. Hoffman comes to stay at Collinwood, posing as a historian, to investigate her private suspicions about Maggie's case.  She discovers exactly what Barnabas is and confronts him -- which is where set 2 ends.This installment continues to expand Barnabas's character beyond simple villain.  I was particularly struck by Barnabas's speech in episode #258 about how he once begged for mercy from those who could have shown it to him, but was shown none -- one of those moments that's especially powerful because of Shakespearean actor Jonathan Frid's delivery.  We get another look at Barnabas's tortured past when Victoria Winters reenacts Josette death during the seance -- which Barnabas tries to percent.  And Barnabas has a  different type of interest in Victoria than he did in Maggie.  He wanted to own and control Maggie -- to trash her identity and replace it with that of Josette.  But he seems to genuinely care for Victoria.  Yes he wants Victoria to assume the persona of Josette, but WILLINGLY because she finds that persona attractive.  Barnabas also has genuine feelings of love and affection for his little sister, Sarah -- no doubt, the same Sarah who helps Maggie escape -- and to be genuinely upset over her having died in childhood.  All in all, Barnabas has become too interesting a character at this point to be dispatched with a hammer and stake, as was the original plan.Another departure from the original plan is the female Dr. Julia Hoffman, who, as I read in the DARK SHADOWS COMPANION, owes her gender to a typo.  The character was originally supposed to be a male doctor named Julian Hoffman --  Julius, according to the DARK SHADOWS ALMANAC -- but somebody mistyped it as Julia.  Dan Curtis saw it and said "Why not?" At the end of episode #290, it becomes apparent that she has something in mind other than killing Barnabas -- and you'll have to buy set 3 to find out what.Returning to Sarah, I'm afraid I don't think Sharon Smyth has the right stuff to pull it off.  Sarah is a very significant character, who will ultimately help persuade Barnabas to change his ways, but Smyth's performance, while remarkably free of flubbed lines, is flat, wooden, and emotionless.A chaaracter I think we could have just done without is Buzz, Carolyn's hippie biker boyfriend.  In the first place, he's an outright caricature, who stands out like a sore thumb among all the fully developed, three-dimensional characters who make DS so distinctive.  In the second place, he seems like an attempt to make the show "relevant" to the `60s, during which this portion of the show was being made.  One often-cited virtue of DS is that it remained immune to the ideology of that era, but this seems to be a lapse.However, DS was forced to make a technical concession to current events in episode #251.  As explained in the DARK SHADOWS ALMANAC, some parts of the country lost a week of DS to a week of O.N.O. hearings on the Vietnam war.  To bring viewers up to speed, ABC provided a summary of the preempted episodes as part of episode #251, but the summary was long enough that it necessitated chopping 45 seconds from the beginning of the first act.Episode #275 is noteworthy for several reasons.  First, if you were getting SICK of hearing, "My name is Victoria Winters,"  at the beginning of every episode, this is where it stops.  Nancy Barrett does the opening for this one, without any "My name is - " involved, and the introductions for all subsequent episodes follow this new pattern.  Second, this is either THE last, or one of the last, episodes to feature a filmed exterior sequence that includes one of the character -- in this case, Carolyn on the beach.  Third, herein is the final convergence of the two plots,currently in progress, with the "Jason blackmailing Liz" story coming to a very final end.  Finally, the confrontation between Jason and Willie is another occasion on which the avoidance of the word "vampire" is particularly obvious.  Note how Willie talks all around it when he tries to warn Jason about Barnabas.You may notice that episode #289 has the grainy sound of a kinescope copy, but a very clear video picture.  As explained in the DARK SHADOWS ALMANAC, episode was originally among those that survive only as kinescopes -- low-quality copies made by filming what's on a video monitor -- until somebody found a Spanish-language version of the videotape.  The video from this was combined with the English-language kinescope soundtrack to make the hybrid we now see.So in the next installment, we'll find out what kind of treatment Barnabas is going to get in place of the hammer and stake.
summary: Barnabas becomes more than a villain, and we meet Sarah and Dr. Hoffman

reviewText: Finally, after years of waiting, Dark Shadows is now on DVD.  It's about time.  This set will begin to close off the Barnabas kidnapping Maggie storyline, and begin to start up the Julia trying to cure Barnabas storyline.  If you are a fan of the show, these DVD sets are a must have.  If you are a fan of gothic horror or classic horror, like the old Hammer films, then this is the series for you.  It's timelessly addictive, and will never die.  A true television legend.  Long live Dark Shadows!
summary: The original remorseful vampire makes his mark on DVD

reviewerName: Eddie Landsberg "My 10th year as a reviewer !...
reviewText: Its said that Dark Shadows didn't really get rolling and gain its claim to immortality until Jonathan Frid entered in the second season... and that's where collection 1 starts.  Amazingly, as you sit through Collection 1 and 2 you can REALLY feel momentum building.  A downside of many DVD collections (and TV series) is that with time you get used to them and start to lose interest.  True cult TV holds up over time, and even moreso, great TV sticks with you for years after the first time you saw it.  Dark Shadows is often described as "short lived" for a soap opera (4 years) but when you consider the fact that the shows were on almost daily and unlike sitcoms and other shows the plots had to continue from episode to episode it is amazing.  - - I literally sat through some of the disks in a day and when they ended my first thought wasn't what to do next - - turn off the TV and get a night of sleep, or continue to watch, watch, watch and watch and get MORE and MORE.  - - 4 or 8 hours of any TV show will usually exhaust you.  Not DARK SHADOWS... the characters are amazing, and at times the acting and dialogue is really edgey...again amazing, because its a soap opera, and also because its a GOTHIC HORROR soap.  How can you combine the reality and human element of a soap with - - vampires and witches and do so in a way that both are packed with emotion and drama???  Apparently the entire cast, production team and writers of DARK SHADOWS knew how... and that's why the DVDs are worth having.  Forget waiting for the reruns to come back on CABLE TV... odds are it'll be cancelled after about a year or they'll jump seasons for some stupid reason.  Own it and resign yourself to fate.  Reality is you will probably be losing a lot of sleep and late for a lot of appointments...  This is CULT TV at its best ! ! !Collection 2 - - in case you're wondering features the introduction of Sarah Collins and Dr. Hoffman.  As the Stoddard-Collins/Jason McGuire thing finally comes to a climax, Barnabus really comes to the forefront.  In case you're watching the show backwards (after having first seen later episodes on TV) an amazing thing to note is the richness of the writing how things are set up and tie together in such an epoch manner !)

reviewText: This Dark Shadows DVD collection #2 contains 4-discs with 40 episodes in all. They are in black & white, but very well made. Uncut & unedited.Last time on Dark Shadows:Maggie Evans has already been bitten twice by Barnabas Collins. He has brain-washed her into believing she is Josette. Barnabas is a 175 year old vampire (no one knows yet, except for Willie) who has an obsession with Josette. She is now a ghost that walks around the old Collins house that Barnabas now has taken up residency in. He does not know there is a ghost in the house. Only young David has seen her. Barnabas continues to make Maggie believe she is Josette and tonight Barnabas intends to make Maggie his eternal bride.  Willie now is a caretaker for Barnabas and he must obey his every order.As we last left Dark Shadows inDark Shadows DVD Collection 1,  Maggie is still strong-minded and knows she is Maggie Evans and has proof that her father, Sam, has been there. In the basement, Maggie was just about to use the stake on Barnabas, but as his coffin opens, she becomes terrified.At the Collinwood Mansion, Elizabeth Stoddard is being blackmailed by Jason McGuire because he knows the truth about the disappearance of her husband, Paul, now missing for 18 years. She knows she killed him. Jason is forcing Elizabeth to marry him. All the clues and secrets are down in the basement of the Collinwood Estate and Carolyn is desperate to find out why her mother has had that room locked for 18 years.Now it is time to see what secrets Collection #2 has to offer.Disc One: June 12--June 23, 1967  Episodes 251-260)These episodes include: John Karlen, Kathryn Leigh Scott, Jonathan Frid, Alexandra Moltke, Nancy Barrett, Joan Bennett, Louis Edmonds, Joel Crothers, Michael Hadge, David Henesy, Dennis Patrick, David Ford, Sharon Smyth, Dana Elcar, Bob O'Connell.Note: Elizabeth Stoddard finally goes outside the estate and into town after 18 years of self-isolation as a widow.Nancy Barrett and David Ford met on the show and married in real-life. It lasted for 2 years.Disc one includes interview with Dan Curtis.__________Disc Two: June 26--July 7, 1967 (Episodes 261-270)Also with Robert Gerringer, Anthony George, Jani Darnaglo, Grayson Hall, Alice Drummond, Clarice Blackburn.The 3 Widows played by Joy Nicholson, Bridget O'Donnell, Marin Riley. Also in appearance: Tom Gorman, hand of Katherine Quint, Jay Gregory, House Jameson.Note: A pivotal wedding ceremony takes place in Collinwood.Disc includes interview with Nancy Barrett__________Disc Three: July 10--July 21, 1967 (Episodes 271-280)Also with Joel Fabiani, Ed Sauter, hand of Barnabas played by Timothy Gordon.In Episode 271, we will see what really happened to Elizabeth Stoddard's husband, Paul.Episode 273 offers another shocking secret.In Episode 276, it is not Victoria Winters voice this time.__________Disc Four: July 24--August 4, 1967 (Episodes 281-290)Dr. Julia Hoffman finds out the truth about Barnabas Collins.Disc includes interview with Alexandra Moltke__________"Costumes by Ohrbach's"Brought to you by MPI Home Video/MPI Media Group.Each episode is approx. 20 minutes long. One disc should only take you 3 hours, 30 minutes to watch.Each episode goes into the next episode. No need to stop and find.It will take you 14 hours plus to watch all 40 episodes in this set.In the next set to buy, color episodes will begin inDark Shadows DVD Collection 3.Update: DARK SHADOWS will be released in the movie theaters May 11, 2012. It will be based on the original ABC Network "Dark Shadows" tv serial (1966-71). Jonathan Frid, Kathryn Leigh Scott, Lara Parker and David Selby make an appearance.Jonathan Frid passed away peacefully in his sleep of natural causes, April 14, 2012. He was 87.SOLD OUT! Dark Shadows: The Complete Original Series set: The first coffin set, "Limited Numbered Edition" with "Autographed Postcard by Jonathan Frid" will be available April 10, 2012. However, some pre-order customers may cancel.Dark Shadows: The Complete Original SeriesThe second coffin set, "Deluxe Edition" will be the complete series, but without the limited edition serial number and autographed postcard. It will be available July 10, 2012.
summary: Maggie is crazy, Barnabas wants his Josette.

reviewText: I always heard that soap operas moved at a crawl, taking forever to get to the point, but as you breeze your way through the forty episodes of "Dark Shadows" that comprise this second collection of the series you will witness all of the following, and then some:1)  The conclusion of the Maggie Evans plotline (or, more precisely, the "Maggie Evans as prisoner of Barnabas" plotline evolves into another type of Maggie Evans storyline).2)  The resolution of the long-running power struggle between Elizabeth Collins Stoddard and Jason McGuire. Highlights here include Elizabeth's daughter becomimg an obnoxious biker chick in response to her mother's arrangement with Mr. McGuire, and a memorable series exit for the gentleman in question.3)  A costume party and seance hosted by Barnabas to mark the completion of his residence's restoration.4)  Barnabas setting his sights on his latest object of affection, and putting a plan in motion to snag her.5)  The nosy Dr. Julia Hoffman going undercover as an historian in an attempt to figure out what had really happened to Maggie Evans during her disappearance, which leads to an absolutely terrific cliff-hanger at the end of the fortieth episode, a cliff-hanger that made me rush to Amazon to order the third collection of episodes!This is the final collection to feature all black-and-white episodes, and all in all the episodes are in very good shape.  Here and there a second generation filmed kinescope fills in the gap where an original videotaped episode was lost, but even those occasional second generation copies are perfectly watchable.  And, like the first collection, this set includes several interviews with cast members, all of whom share engaging anecdotes about the series.As a "Dark Shadows" novice that enjoyed the first DVD collection of the series, I'm still firmly on board after recently finishing this second collection, which I enjoyed even more.
summary: Creepy and fun, Dark Shadows Collection 2 is a winner
Title: N/A

reviewText: The chills continue! Dark Shadows DVD Collection 2 is great and you can feel the momentum and the suspense building as you watch it.Maggie Evans escapes from the Old House basement where Barnabas as her kidnapped, with the help of his younger sister Sarah.Dr.Julia Hoffman is introduced as Maggie's physician and quickly figures out the secret of Barnabas Collins.Jason McGuire meets his demise when Barnabas hand reaches out from the coffin and grabs his throat! Also,Barnabas as his eyes on Victoria Winters becoming his new Josette!In this collection some old storylines came to an end thereby giving way to the momentum for the next stories to build up suspensfully.The best episodes in this collection are #260-where Maggie escapes from Barnabas, #271-when Elizabeth reveals what happened at Collinwood 18 years ago,#281-where Victoria relieves the death of Josette and #290-where Barnabas comes to Julia's room to strangle her and surprisedly finds Julia waiting for him.These episodes are all frightfully scary!MPI should have done some restoration work on these or cleaned them up a bit,but the episodes are in good condition considering the time(1967) and the age of the prints,as well as the audio.There are also bonus interviews with Dan Curtis(Creator & executive Producer),Nancy Barrett(Carolyn Stoddard),Dennis Patrick(Jason McGuire) and Alexandra Moltke(Victoria Winters).The voice-over-"My name is Victoria Winters..." is heard for the last time in this collection.The disappointment here is there are no English subtitles and the episodes are not close-captioned.Jonathan Frid is superb as Barnabas Collins,as always;and casting Grayson Hall as Dr.Julia Hoffman was a stroke of genius! The rest of the cast are great in their  respective roles.I will always have memories from my childhood of running home when school was out to sit in front of a black and white television set to watch DARK SHADOWS!
Title: N/A

reviewText: ABC's supernatural soap which ran from 1966-71 with over 1000 eps by Dan Curtis ... Intended to be a Wuthering Heights-like drama, for about 200 episodes before a supernatural character takes over ... Barnabus Collins the vampire. Right where Amazon picks up the Instant here...Then all bets are off, we get witches, werewolves, golems, phoenixes, ghosts galore & whatever the heck Quentin is. The concept is surprisingly timely now that the period supernaturals (Pride & Prejudice & Zombies) are so hip... Curtis' original Dark Shadows is Delightfully low budget... And on mostly live daytime tv time constraints there are lots of mistakes... And why it rocks. When compared to the mind-numbing mediocrity of most on screen scenes the descriptions of Barnabas' hinted off-screen exploits are amazingly dynamic... Like the ransacking of the doctor's office to get Maggie's blood sample. In typical soap fashion story-lines creep along taking appalling amounts of time to climax, constraints of the live-to-tape format lead to classic goofs too.
summary: Great place to start your Amazon instant introduction to Collinsport!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed Collection 2 much more than Collection 1. The pace picks up a bit and the story becomes much more interesting. Jonathan Frid is superb as Barnabas Collins. Mr. Frid plays the guilt-ridden vampire with grace, romanticism and passion. John Karlen does a splendid job playing Willie Lumis as he always seems to be on the verge of a nervous breakdown. Grayson Hall is great in portraying the smart and courageous Dr. Hoffman. I love the rooms in the old house as they are beautifully done. The candles and the music go hand in hand and effectively transport the viewer to an earlier and gentler time adding an eerie but desirable touch. The show is just as addictive now as it was when it first came out in the 60's. It leaves the viewer wanting more. Looking forward to Collection 3.

Includes interviews and is really worth the money, new or used.  Vampire fans has to have this in their library.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Just in case there are still people on the planet that aren't aware of the basics of this show -*********************SPOILERS POSSIBLE******************************************This group of episodes continues the trials and tribulations of Maggie Evans who is imprisoned by the evil vampire Barnabas Collins. Barnabas wishes to turn her into his lost love Josette Collins and make her one of the undead. When Maggie escapes and is presumed dead, Barnabas turns his sights on governess Victoria Winters, who is drawn to the legends of Josette. New to the series is Dr. Julia Hoffman who comes a-snooping trying to get at the truth of Maggie's mysterious attacker, as well as the mysterious *little girl* Sarah who can come and go at will even through locked doors and is dressed in colonial attire.I was one of those young girls who had to rush home from school everyday in time to catch the latest episode, and I found these still highly entertaining despite the campiness of it all. The acting and story holds up well and I do plan on continuing the series. I did find some episodes in this group a bit wearing as they wrapped up the Jason McGuire blackmail bit. That said, I really enjoyed Carolyn's rebellion especially when she hooked up with biker bad dude Buzz and his biker get up - PRICELESS. This edition contains four DVD's with I believe forty episodes plus an interview with cast members at the end of each one and ones I enjoyed best were the actresses who played Carolyn and Victoria. They were still lovely after all these years - nice to see. A definite must for fans of this old cult classic.
summary: Some slower moments in this group of episodes..

reviewText: I was 9 years old when Dark Shadows debuted on TV.  My mother did not allow me to watch it but when she wasn't home, I did.  Barnabus Collins and all the Collins family are here on DVD to remember many years later.  Now, as an adult, I understand much more in the show than I did back then.  These episodes are recorded as originally taped, mistakes and all and that makes them even more fun to watch!  I look forward to purchasing more of the Dark Shadows collections.

reviewText: When I finished watching the first DVD collection of `Dark Shadows', I immediately purchased this set in order to see what happened to the lives of the residents of Collinwood. Now having finished watching this set, I must say that I am not one bit disappointed. The storyline were so intriguing that I saw around 10 episodes in 1 day.Some of the plots in this collection include:- Maggie Evan's escape from Barnabas Collins- Elizabeth Collin's engagement to Jason McGuire- Revelation of Elizabeth Collin's deepest secret- Victoria Winter's sudden liking for Josette.- Dr. Julia Hoffman finding out another secret about a member of the Collins family.This collection will keep you entertained for hours. You will not notice the time fly by once you start watching the episodes. The cast give amazing performances in this show, and I especially like Kathryn Leigh Scott's performance as Maggie Evans. Even though this show aired in the 60s, it still continues to entertain many, which proves how good this show is! I am off to buy the next set of the series to view the continuation.

reviewText: This show has an odd appeal, a vampire, old houses, the sheer cliff with the rocks below and the roiling sea. Even though everyone knows that the show is shot on a very cheap set, one has to pretend a bit. I like the idea of the show but I must confess that this show is the BEST sleep aid anywhere. I watch a couple to a few of these episodes, and if I am tired, damn, I am out like a light. Yes, I can usually turn off the dvd player, but not always. This show just puts me to sleep like nothing else on dvd. I like the character of Barnabus Collins. The guy is a good actor. He carries the show. I like old shows. I like reliving the past. I like to be scared. I like horror and vampires, and on and on. This show has an appeal, even if it moves at a mind numbingly SLOW pace.That being said, damn, I have never seen such shoddy light work and so on. It seems that in almost every frame I see the silhouette of a microphone. It's pretty annoying to see a six inch shadow on the side of a character's head. It also really SUCKS to see shadows moving when the characters are not moving and when the room should otherwise be empty. And how about SHAKEY VISION. How many times are we all watching the camera frame bouncing around? God, the people who did the light and camera work on this show must have been bored to death or on drugs, or they found some college film majors and gave them some cameras and microphones. I basically don't keep friends and so I have no social life. So I likes me some tv. I have watched a ton of tv shows from old to modern but I have never seen such lousy lighting and behind the scenes work. I swear I just talk to the tv all the time when I watch this show. I am either mocking the slow pace of the show, or the stupid redundant dialogue or the god awful intrusion of microphones silhouetted on drapes, character's clothes, on their damned faces. JEEZ. And I am almost at the end of collection 2. I don't know why I bought collection 2 after one. I guess I hoped to see a lot of improvement and to see some more of the story. God, I hope the technical people get their act together eventually. I hope Mrs Winters stops giving those dumbass monologues too. I also hope something HAPPENS.Ok, collection two, the old woman did NOT kill her HUSBAND.The guy blackmailing the old woman dies a greedy stupid man's death at the hand's of Barnabus the vampire. Of course we saw no carnage of any kind though.Barnabus sets his eyes on Miss Winters. She will be the next what's her name Collins.I'm trying hard to enjoy this but it just quite stupid overall. If I had never been a little scared of this show as a child, and if it wasn't just a tiny bit of the tapestry of my life I don't think I'd ever watch any of this at all. I'm just trying to educate myself a bit on the legacy of this show. Dark Shadows was like a bad slow book that one had to read for a college class.Sorry Barnabus, you were interesting but wow, how DULL and slow everything was.And the blonde gal Carolyn was good looking for sure and she had great hair. And Miss Winters was a babe too. And that one young guy was the first captain on Star Trek. : )I hope there won't be a test because as anyone can see I'd do poorly unless it was multiple choice. I sure can't fill in the blanks.
summary: Why do I watch this show?

reviewText: The first season was good - but the second season is even better. The storyline is more involved and the introduction of Grayson Hall as Dr. Julia Hoffman is a major plus. She is a classic actress and plays the role of Maggie's mysterious doctor brilliantly. Though Maggie Evans is still a key player in the second season, the show doesn't revolve around her as much, (which is good as her screaming and whining get a bit irritating), and the other characters' roles are better defined. And of course Jonathan Frid is always perfect in the role of Barnabas Collins. I can't wait to start watching the third collection.
summary: And it just keeps getting better!

reviewText: My wife and I weren't sure we wanted to try volume 2 after watching the show spend such an absurd amount of time on Maggie Evans without much developing.  We were constantly teased in vol. 1 as plotlines seemed about to go somewhere, and then stopped short and switched into reverse.Vol. 2 really changes this.  We're half way through disc 3 now, and have seen the end of two major plotlines that we never thought would go anywhere.  The show continues to surprise us, episode after episode, by confidently charging into new territory, throwing new twists and turns at us whenever possible.Perhaps most surprising in this volume is the enjoyable break we get from Barnabus and Willy.  While vol. 1 practically depended upon the two of them rescuing us from the tedious bore of the Collins/ Stoddard family, vol. 2 gets us very involved in the affairs of Liz Stoddard, Jason MaGuire, Carolyn Stoddard, and even Vickie Winters and Burke Devlin.  We hardly notice how long we go without seeing Barnabus and Willy so that, when they finally reappear, the writers and actors have had a chance to really think about the characters and develop them better.All in all, vol. 2 is light years ahead of volume 1.  The characters are more interesting and the plots are more compelling.  If the lull in the second half of vol. 1 left you with a bad taste in your mouth, vol. 2 will gladly wash it away!
summary: The series finally takes on some real momentum with vol. 2!

reviewText: I'm going to review the content of Collection 2 instead of the series like the other reviewers here.  It should be mentioned that the 8 weeks of episodes on collection 2 are a big improvement over collection 1 which was good, but a little slow at times.  By these episodes, the writers seemed to have figured out what to do with Barnabas and a few old stale plot lines are tossed to the curb.  I think that new fans who bought collection 1 but were on the fence about whether to check out collection 2 or not should go ahead and give it a try.  I'm convinced the improved pacing of these episodes will make you a fan!
